Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Expectation2: Participate in community rituals and ceremonies
Situation2: A community memorial service at the temple takes place tonight with many attendees expected.
Story: I watched my younger brother tighten his helmet, his eyes shining with excitement as he eyed the steep, uneven ramp in our neighborhood park. He’d been practicing for weeks, determined to master this new skateboard trick, and he wanted me there to cheer him on. As his older sibling, I felt the weight of responsibility—if anything happened, I’d never forgive myself. But tonight was also the community memorial service at the temple, a ceremony I’d promised to attend. As a Buddhist, I was expected to be present, to help set up, and to chant with the others for those who had passed. My teacher had reminded me how important it was to support the sangha, especially during rituals that brought comfort to grieving families. I stood at the edge of the ramp, my phone buzzing with reminders from both worlds—my brother’s hopeful grin on one side, the gentle insistence of my Buddhist community on the other. My heart pounded as I tried to decide where I was needed most, torn between the safety of my family and the spiritual obligations I’d embraced.
